III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures that address all of the following: (e)
Dispensing medication.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff were not giving Youth A her Trazadone when she first
arrived because they said they did not prescribe sleep aides. They
finally started giving it to her at night. The staff gives her Adderall
capsule, but they open it and dissolve it into a glass of water
which is not as effective.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 5/16/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Complainant reported Youth
A was without medication for a week once entering the facility.
Youth A’s mother requested medication be given but was told “the
facility does not provide sleeping medication”. Complainant also
reported the nursing staff is providing Adderall but breaks open
the capsule and mixes the medication with water which she
believes cuts down on the effect of the medication. Complainant
reported Youth A is having racing thoughts and has struggled with
mental illness since age 3. Complainant also reported Youth A is
so upset at the facility that Youth A may “take her own life” and the
facility is refusing to provide therapy for Youth A.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone 5/16/2024. He
reported not knowing about the allegations but does know Youth
2

A. He also reported Youth A has been doing well and there have
been no concerns with Youth A’s behaviors.
Administrator 1 and Administrator 2 were interviewed face-to-
face at the facility on 5/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. Both reported Youth A entered the facility on 5/2/24 and
has presented with no behavior issues. They also reported all
health care (medical and mental health) issues are handled by the
contracted Nursing department and a contracted Psychiatrist.
Both also reported Probation Officer must approve an outside
therapist for Youth A, but Youth A has access to a therapist
through the “Network 180” program at the facility.
Administrator 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Administrator 3
reported the process of providing medication for youth is to verify
the medication, get verbal consent to treat by the guardian/parent,
and then get a written consent to treat. One the youth has been
assessed by the contracted Psychiatrist, then the guardian/parent
is notified of the outcome of the assessment. This will involve what
medication is being provided. Administrator 3 also reported the
Psychiatrist is not available each Wednesday, as the reason
Youth A had to wait until 5/15/24 for a full assessment.
Administrator 3 reported Youth A entered the facility with no
medication and Youth A’s mother had no medication at the time.
Youth A’s mother provided medication on 5/3/24 (Abilify and
Trazodone which were refilled on 4/15/24 and Youth A’s mother
had over 30 pills in her possession) and verbal consent to treat on
5/4/24. After the assessment, the Psychiatrist approved Youth A
to begin taking Abilify and Adderall but not Trazodone.
Administrator 3 reported this decision was made because Youth A
had not taken the medication as needed since she was AWOL for
14 months prior to entering the program. Administrator 3 reported
Youth A’s mother was upset with this decision. Administrator 3
reported the staff have not reported Youth A is struggling to sleep
and Youth A has not showed signs of being tired during school
classes. Administrator 3 reported because Youth A’s mother’s
constantly demands medication be given to Youth A, the
Psychiatrist agreed to begin the Trazodone. Youth A was
compliant in taking the medication and was evaluated by the
Psychiatrist on 5/15/24 who recommended continuing the
medication. In regard to giving the Adderall without the capsule,
Administrator 3 reported this was approved by the Psychiatrist and
is an approved method of dispensing this type of medication.
Administrator 3 reported staff are not mixing the medication in
water but removing the medication from the capsule and placing
3

the medication in a cup. Youth A is then given a cup of water and
takes the medication and washes it down with the water.
Regarding the issue of not receiving therapy, Administrator 3
reported the process to have a therapist other than the contracted
Network180 therapist is for the Probation Officer to set up therapy.
Administrator 3 reported Probation Officer has been contacted on
this issue. Administrator 3 reported no concerns with the nursing
staff, and it is only the nursing staff that dispense medication to
youth. If there is ever a question, the nursing staff will check with
the doctor and nursing staff never prescribe medication or make
medication changes on their own.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
5/17/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A
reported being AWOL for 14 months before being placed in the
facility. She reported being caught by Law Enforcement as the
reason her AWOL statues changed. She reported not taking any
of her medication (Adderall, Ability, and Trazodone) while AWOL
and using marijuana to self-medicate. Youth A reported beginning
to take Adderall the second day in the facility and Trazodone a
few days later. She contributes this change to her mother’s
intervention. She reported being given the Adderall as reported by
Administrator 3. This involves the capsule being opened and the
medication poured into a cup. She is then given a cup of water to
wash the medication down with. Youth A reported taking the
medication as prescribed each day and hasn’t missed any days
since starting the medication. Youth A reported having no issues
sleeping. Youth A reported speaking to the Network 180 therapist
three times but would rather speak to the therapist she worked
with in the past. She believed the Network 180 therapist is not
helping. Youth A reported feeling safe in the facility and having her
needs met. She reported being treated well and has no concerns.
Probation Officer was interviewed via phone on 5/21/2024.
She reported not being surprised by the concerns because Youth
A’s mother has threatened to take it to the next level in an effort to
get the Judge who is overseeing the case with Youth A, changed.
Probation Officer reported Youth A has had no contact with the
therapist the court provided through “girls court” since going
AWOL over a year ago. She reported Youth A is eligible to be
seen for therapy through the Network 180 and there are two
therapist through this program at the facility. Probation Officer has
no concerns about the allegations and believe the allegations to
be unfounded.
4

Youth B was interviewed via phone on 5/24/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported taking Adderall
and described the process the same as Administrator 3 reported.
The drug is removed from the capsule and placed in a paper cup,
and he is given a cup of water. He reported only nursing staff
provide his medication and all youth’s medication. He feels safe at
the facility and has no issues at the facility. He has used Network
180 when needed to speak to a therapist and believed this
interaction with a Network 180 therapist has been very helpful.
Nurse 6 was interviewed face to face on 5/28/2024 at the
facility. She reported the process of giving Adderall medication
the same as Administrator 3, Youth A, and Youth B. She reported
the memo came out a few years ago about the need to make this
change of removing the substance from the capsules because
youth were cheeking their medication and this method keeps them
from taking this action. Nurse 6 reported working in the mornings
and will administer medication to Youth A when working. She
reported Youth A has been compliant with the medication and has
had no report of Youth A not being able to sleep.
Nurse 5 was interviewed via phone on 5/31/2024. He reported
the same as Nurse 6 when administering Adderall. The capsule is
opened, and the drug is placed in a cup. Youth can take the
medication with water or without, it is their preference.
Documents Reviewed:
Patient Note dated 5/2/24 for Youth A authored by Nurse 2.
This note documents that verbal consent to treat was given by
Youth A’s mother at this time. It also documents Youth A has not
been taking medication and Youth A’s mother will drop of the
medication she has later in the day.
Patient Note dated 5/3/24 for Youth A authored by Nurse 2.
This note documents that Youth A’s mother again asked about
bringing medication.
Patient Note dated 5/3/24 for Youth A authored by Nurse 1.
This note documents that Youth A’s mother came to the facility
with medication (unidentified) and reported Youth A has a pattern
of taking her medication for a couple of days before going AWOL
for several days. Youth A’s mother reported Youth A wants to
control the medication but is very sporadic in taking the
medication. The pharmacy is closed at this time so Doctor will be
5

contacted in the morning about administrating the medication.
Youth A’s mother signed the medical consent form.
Patient Note dated 5/4/24 for Youth A authored by Nurse 1.
This note documents nursing staff received an order from Doctor
for Adderall but not Trazodone for Youth A.
Patient Note dated 5/4/24 for Youth A authored by Nurse 1.
This note documents that Youth A’s medication was verified with
the pharmacy and the Adderall was ordered by Doctor.
Patient Note dated 5/5/24 for Youth A authored by Nurse 1.
This note documents Nurse 1 speaking with Youth A’s mother and
Youth A’s mother being upset because Youth A is not taking
Abilify with the Adderall. Youth A’s mother was asked to bring in
the Ability, but she reported not having any Abilify. Youth A’s
mother was told Youth A is on Doctor’s list to discuss Youth A’s
medication.
Text messages dated 5/8/24 between Doctor and Nurse 2. This
text is from the Nurse 2 to Doctor. It is documented Youth A’s
mother dropped off Ability. Nurse 2 asked Doctor if it is possible to
give Youth A Trazodone before the assessment since Youth A’s
mother is upset and Youth A is reporting that she is not sleeping.
Doctor responds with “give it”.
Psychiatric Provider Follow-Up DH-12.1 dated 5/15/24 for
Youth A and authored by Doctor. This document lists the
current medication Youth A is taking.
MAR by Month dated May 2024 for Youth A. This document
identifies medication provided for Youth A each day of the month.
• Trazodone is documented as being taken by Youth A
starting on 5/8/2024 until 5/16/24 (day document provided
by facility). This medication is approved and prescribed by
Doctor, and it is documented the following nursing staff
provided the medication to Youth A. Nurse 2, Nurse 3,
Nurse 4, and Nurse 5. Youth A is documented as being
100% compliant with this medication.
• Aripiprazole (Ability oral) is documented as being taken by
Youth A starting on 5/8/2024 until 5/16/24 (day document
provided by facility). This medication is approved and
prescribed by Doctor, and it is documented the following
nursing staff provided the medication to Youth A. Nurse 2,
6

Nurse 3, Nurse 4, and Nurse 5. Youth A is documented as
being 100% compliant with this medication.
• Amphetamine/Dextroamphetamine (Adderall oral) is
documented as being taken by Youth A starting on
5/5/2024 until 5/16/24 (day document provided by facility).
This medication is approved and prescribed by Doctor, and
it is documented the following nursing staff provided the
medication to Youth A. Nurse 2, Nurse 3, Nurse 4, Nurse 5,
and Administrator 3. Youth A is documented as being
100% compliant with this medication.
Telephone/Verbal Orders Psychiatric Provider – PO-1.1
Doctor dated 5/4/24 authored by Nurse 1. This document
outlines the order for Adderall 30 MG 1 time daily in the morning.
VitalCore Health Strategies PO-12.0 Medication Verification
for Youth A dated 5/3/24. This document outlines the medication
from the pharmacy Youth A will be receiving as Trazodone 50 MG
and Adderall 30 MG, Nurse 1 signed to verify this information. It is
also noted Adderall was ordered but Trazodone was not ordered
at this time.
Email from Administrator 3 to Probation Officer on 5/9/24.
Administrator is asking Probation Officer about Therapist’s
interactions in detention with Youth A. Probation Officer responds
with Youth A being AWOL for over a year and believing Youth A
has not been in therapy with Therapist. Probation Officer noted
Youth A was seeing Therapist when Youth A was involved in “girls
court”. Administrator 3 asks if Youth A is able to see Therapist.
Email from Administrator 3 to all clinic staff working in
detention dated 4/26/23. This document indicates all stimulants
with the exception of Concerta, capsules are to be opened and
floated in water.
VitalCore Health Strategies Personal Medication Log dated
2020. This medication log is for Youth A and documents on 5/3/24
Trazodone (16 pills) and Amphetamine (12 pills) were received.
This document was signed by Nurse 1.
VitalCore Health Strategies Health Services Policy and
Procedure G-02.01 dated 9/10/21. This document outlines that
the facility will follow this procedure with site-specific process
and/or modifications. The specific procedure involves using
Network 180 for Social Work and all youth upon intake will be
referred to Network 180 for evaluation. Network 180 is to make
7

any referral to medical or mental health as seen fit. The Network
180 Psychiatrist is on-site every Wednesday but the 2nd
Wednesday of every month.
Kent County Juvenile Detention Center Medical Consent
Form dated 5/2/24 and signed by Youth A’s mother. This
document gives the facility consent for medical treatment for
Youth A while at the facility.
VitalCore Health Services Policy and Procedure – Medication
Services D-02.00 dated 7/1/2023. This document outlines the
medical services provided to youth at the facility. It is documented
that prescription medications are given only by order of a
physician. Youth entering the facility on prescription medications
must have these medications verified to continue receiving the
medications. In the case of a need to order medications if the
medication will not be available for 72 hours, then an order to the
back-up pharmacy for enough medication to cover the period of
72 hours. Medication brought to the facility by a parent of the
youth must also be verified as the actual medication and in the
original appropriately labeled container.
VitalCore Health Services Policy and Procedure – Nursing
Clinical Guidelines E-11.00 dated 10/1/2023. This document
outlines the medical care provided to youth. It is documented that
all “standing orders” are approved by the Chief Medical consultant
or the Deputy Chief Medical Officer.
VitalCore Health Services Policy and Procedure – Continuity,
Coordination and Quality of Care During Incarceration E-
12.00 dated 10/1/2023. This document outlines that health care is
monitored from admission per prescriber’s recommendations,
orders, and evidence-based practices.
Medication sheet for Youth B dated 5/24/24. This document
outlines the two medications Youth B is taking while lodged at the
facility. Youth B is taking Amphetamine (Adderall) once day and
Fluoxetine once per day.
Unit (Charlie) Logs for Youth A dated 5/2/24 to 5/17/24. There
is no documentation that Youth A was awake or struggling to
sleep in these logs. The logs were documented between 10:40 pm
and 6:30 am each day. Youth A was quite or asleep throughout
the night.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, and documents reviewed medicine was and is being
8

administered as ordered by Doctor and the procedures developed
by the nursing department and facility. It should also be noted that
therapeutic services are available to Youth A through Network
180.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
